nbme_correct_explanation: This patient's history of emphysema and smoking, as well as his signs and symptoms of decreased breath sounds at the left lung base, muscular weakness that improves with exertion, reduced deep tendon reflexes, and autonomic dysfunction (including dry mouth and erectile dysfunction) are concerning for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). LEMS is an uncommon neurologic condition involving formation of antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels at the neuromuscular junction, commonly as a paraneoplastic phenomenon in association with small cell lung carcinoma. Normally, voltage-gated calcium channels at the axonal terminal bouton open following depolarization, allowing calcium influx, and triggering exocytosis of neurotransmitter-filled vesicles into the synaptic cleft. In LEMS, antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels prevent terminal axonal calcium influx and release of acetylcholine to postsynaptic skeletal muscle cells. Patients classically display a triad of muscular weakness, depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes, and autonomic dysfunction. The muscle weakness and areflexia typically improve with exercise as amounts of acetylcholine accumulate in the synaptic cleft. Autonomic symptoms may include orthostasis, decreased salivation, dry eyes, and erectile dysfunction. Ocular and bulbar symptoms may occur later in the disease following onset of proximal muscle weakness and may include dysphagia, diplopia, and ptosis. The diagnosis is confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Choice A) is a genetic disorder that presents with slowly progressive, symmetric motor and sensory polyneuropathy that begins in the distal lower extremities, resulting in skeletal deformities such as hammer toes or pes cavus, and may progress to the upper extremities. Patients typically have a positive family history.

Inclusion body myositis (IBM) (Choice B) is an autoimmune inflammatory condition affecting the proximal and distal muscles that presents with progressive muscle weakness and increased serum creatine kinase concentration. In contrast to other inflammatory myopathies that have a predilection for proximal muscles, distal weakness of the hands and ankles is a prominent and early finding. IBM does not typically present with autonomic dysfunction or areflexia and is not associated with lung carcinoma.

Myasthenia gravis (MG) (Choice C) is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by the formation of inhibitory antiacetylcholine receptor autoantibodies. Common symptoms include muscular weakness, fatigue, diplopia, and ptosis that worsens toward the end of the day, along with dysphagia and potential respiratory distress. Patients may present with an associated thymoma. In contrast to LEMS, MG typically displays more prominent involvement of the upper extremities and earlier and more prominent ocular and bulbar findings. Autonomic dysfunction and areflexia are atypical of MG. In addition, muscular weakness in MG worsens, rather than improves, with repeated exertion.

Polymyositis (Choice E) is an autoimmune inflammatory condition affecting the proximal muscles. It is closely related to dermatomyositis; however, unlike dermatomyositis, it does not present with cutaneous findings. The muscular inflammation is characterized by endomysial CD8+ inflammatory infiltrate causing damage to the myocytes. Unlike LEMS, polymyositis typically presents with pain and stiffness of the affected muscles. Transient improvement in weakness with repeated exertion does not occur.

nbme_correct_explanation: Hepatic encephalopathy is commonly associated with decompensated liver cirrhosis. Signs of hepatic encephalopathy include confusion, stupor, asterixis, tremor, and myoclonus on physical examination. Hepatic encephalopathy results from accumulation of ammonia produced by colonic bacteria. Serum ammonia concentrations in patients with hepatic encephalopathy may be increased, though this is not necessary for the diagnosis. Treatments for hepatic encephalopathy include rifaximin and lactulose. Rifaximin is a gut-selective, nonabsorbable antibiotic with activity against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. It acts on the beta subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to inhibit bacterial synthesis and is bactericidal. Lactulose is degraded by colonic bacteria to create an acidic environment, thereby converting ammonia to ammonium, which cannot be readily absorbed across the gut wall. It is then excreted with feces, lowering total body levels.

Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal that presents with severe confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability.

Expressive aphasia (Choice B), or Broca aphasia, is caused by injury to the Broca area within the frontal lobe of the brain. Patients with expressive (Broca) aphasia can comprehend language but have a difficult time forming sentences, connecting words, and producing speech.
Receptive aphasia (Choice C), or Wernicke aphasia, is caused by injury to the Wernicke area within the temporal lobe. Patients with receptive (Wernicke) aphasia can generate words and sounds but often cannot produce intelligible speech.
Dissociative fugue (Choice D) refers to a complete loss of memory associated with wandering behavior. This pattern of behavior may be seen in dissociative identity disorder or may be caused by a recent traumatic exposure.

Neurosyphilis (Choice F) typically presents with progressive dementia or tabes dorsalis (disease of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord). Delirium and asterixis would be atypical. Patients may demonstrate a tabetic gait (a wide-based, purposeful gait).
Wernicke encephalopathy (Choice G), caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, often in association with alcohol use disorder, is characterized by altered mental status, confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. This patient's condition is more consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and lacks consistent features of Wernicke encephalopathy. Propranolol and primidone are both effective first-line agents. Propranolol has fewer known drug-drug interactions and a better tolerated adverse effect profile. nbme_correct_explanation: Dizziness and gait instability carries a broad differential diagnosis, and is often divided into central, peripheral, and secondary causes of symptoms to determine a likely diagnosis. Central causes include cerebrovascular accidents such as ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes, tumors of the brainstem and cerebellum, infarction involving the vestibulocochlear nerve, and multiple sclerosis or similar demyelinating disorders. Peripheral causes include benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, labyrinthitis, Meniere disease, endolymphatic fistula, or temporal bone fractures, tumors, or lesions. Secondary or systemic causes can include electrolyte imbalances, hypovolemia, cardiac arrhythmia, infections, and vitamin deficiencies, among other causes. This patient likely has labyrinthitis, an inflammation of the inner ear, often involving the vestibulocochlear nerve and often preceded by an upper respiratory or ear infection. Classic symptoms include vertigo, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and hearing loss. Treatment is supportive, along with the exclusion of emergent causes of vertigo and ataxia, as the condition is typically self-limited.

Over time, thiamine deficiency can result in damage and atrophy of the mammillary bodies, visible on MRI of the brain, which manifests as Wernicke encephalopathy. To prevent Wernicke encephalopathy, all patients with sustained heavy alcohol use should be given oral thiamine supplementation, and patients presenting with acute intoxication should generally be given parenteral thiamine. The typical clinical presentation of Wernicke encephalopathy is a triad of acutely altered mental status, ophthalmoplegia (along with nystagmus), and ataxia. The symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy are reversible but increase the risk for developing Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcohol users if not immediately treated with high-dose parenteral thiamine. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is an irreversible condition that features psychosis, anterograde and retrograde amnesia, and the consequent tendency to confabulate, or verbalize false stories or memories, to compensate for the inability to remember.

nbme_correct_explanation: This patient has physical examination findings consistent with normal aging. Normal aging includes a slow decline of executive functioning, attention span, and problem-solving after age 70 years. The central nervous system is affected greatly by the aging process, and there are characteristic findings consistent with normal aging that every physician should be familiar with. One of the most common neurologic changes to occur is the loss of vibratory sensation, primarily in the distal extremities, as seen in this patient. Other findings include decreased to absent deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) (especially in the ankle), decreased pupillary response to light, presbyopia, and decreased hearing. As a patient ages, their gait often becomes broad-based and their stride shortens. Changes associated with sleep include a decrease in REM sleep and sleep onset latency, and an increase in nighttime awakenings. It is crucial for physicians to be familiar with these changes and be able to distinguish them from pathologic findings.

Symptoms are most predominant in the upper extremities. Lumbar spinal stenosis (Choice B) refers to the narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal, which results in compression of the lumbar nerve roots or spinal cord. Patients classically present with low back pain that radiates to the buttocks and lower extremities that worsens with spinal extension and improves with spinal flexion. Peripheral neuropathy (Choice D) has many causes, including metabolic, toxic, autoimmune, and/or hereditary neuropathy. nbme_correct_explanation: Syncope is a common presenting finding with numerous causes. Vasovagal syncope is caused by a disordered autonomic nervous system response with increased parasympathetic and decreased sympathetic activity. This results in an acute decrease in peripheral vascular resistance with simultaneous bradycardia, decreased cardiac output, and an inability to maintain perfusion to the brain. Symptoms often follow a specific trigger such as standing for long periods of time, heat, intense emotion, the sight of blood, or pain. The onset of symptoms is typically gradual over several seconds and associated with nausea, light-headedness, dizziness, visual disturbances, pallor, and/or diaphoresis. A careful history that evaluates for provoking factors and physical examination can guide further diagnostic studies and is essential for differentiating vasovagal syncope from other potential causes of syncope, such as cardiac syncope, seizure, hypoglycemia, or transient ischemic attack. The diagnosis is clinical, although a diagnostic evaluation is often performed to exclude other diagnoses. Tilt testing may reproduce vasovagal symptoms and is helpful when the diagnosis is uncertain. For most patients, avoidance of risk factors is the only necessary treatment.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Carcinoid syndrome (Choice A) is a rare disorder that results from the production of serotonin by a carcinoid tumor. Symptoms include weight loss, flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm, right-sided cardiac valvular disease, and abdominal pain. Flushing and bronchospasm are typically episodic, though the other symptoms are constant and not found in this patient.

Drop attack (Choice B) is a nonspecific term that refers to a sudden fall without an associated loss of consciousness, which may occur for a variety of neurologic, vascular, or orthopedic reasons.

Herpes simplex (Choice C) is a common cause of viral meningitis, which presents with fever, headache, obtundation, seizures, and meningismus.

Seizure disorders (Choice D) are variable in presentation but typically present with the sudden onset of muscle contractions followed by rhythmic jerking of the extremities. Bowel and/or bladder incontinence commonly occurs. Episodes are accompanied by a postictal state marked by confusion and fatigue. Preceding symptoms of light-headedness and flushing, as well as the presence of sinus bradycardia, are more consistent with vasovagal syncope.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Choice E) presents with acute, severe headache, fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma. The absence of headache in this patient suggests an alternate diagnosis.

Transient ischemic attack (Choice F) is a transient episode of focal neurologic dysfunction caused by central nervous system ischemia without infarction. The focal symptoms last less than 24 hours by definition and may last as little as a few minutes. This patient's brief symptoms with complete resolution and absence of sequelae or risk factors suggest against the diagnosis.

nbme_correct_explanation: Shearing of the bridging veins in the subdural space is the cause of subdural hematoma (SDH). Head trauma, the use of anticoagulants, physical abuse, alcohol use disorder, cerebral atrophy, and malignancy are associated with an increased risk for SDH. On imaging, SDH appears as a crescent-shaped collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines. In some cases, the SDH may be large enough to compress adjacent brain parenchyma, displacing the cerebral hemisphere. Thus, presentation can include subacute-onset headache, focal neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizures, herniation syndromes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure such as vomiting and papilledema. Patients may manifest upper motor neuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which places traction on bridging cortical veins. In this setting, minor trauma such as falls can result in shearing of the veins leading to hemorrhage. Untreated, the SDH may continue to grow. The intracranial compartment is a fixed space within a rigid skull; pathologic lesions such as SDH can result in midline shift and herniation of central nervous system structures if large enough. Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery leads to contralateral hemiparesis and contralateral sensory deficit of the face and upper extremities. Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery supplying the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) leads to aphasia, while occlusion of the middle cerebral artery supplying the nondominant hemisphere results in hemineglect.

B) Colchicine
C) Gabapentin
D) Ibuprofen
E) Prednisone
nbme_correct_explanation: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition characterized by proximal muscle and joint (e.g., shoulder and hip girdle) pain, stiffness, and increased inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. If untreated, muscle weakness may occur from disuse atrophy. Systemic symptoms such as fatigue are commonly noted. It is most common in patients over age 60 years, and some patients have associated temporal arteritis. Signs of temporal arteritis such as throbbing temporal headache, vision changes, or jaw claudication should prompt temporal artery biopsy. The diagnosis of PMR is based on clinical features, and treatment is with prednisone for up to 1 year. It is common for patients to respond to prednisone almost immediately; thus, the absence of response should prompt consideration of a different diagnosis.
nbme_incorrect_explanation: Azathioprine (Choice A) is a purine analogue commonly used as an immunosuppressive agent in organ transplantation and inflammatory conditions. Adverse effects include hepatotoxicity and leukopenia, as well as headaches, vomiting, and diarrhea. It is not used in the treatment of PMR. Colchicine (Choice B) is used to treat inflammatory arthritis and pericarditis and is classically used in the treatment of gout. It inhibits microtubule formation, thereby preventing white blood cell translocation into the joint, which limits joint space inflammation and associated arthropathy. It is not used in the treatment of PMR. Gabapentin (Choice C) is commonly used in patients with painful peripheral neuropathy. It does not treat the underlying inflammation of PMR and is not used as a treatment for this condition. Ibuprofen (Choice D) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that inhibits the COX enzyme. Adverse effects include gastritis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and nephropathy. It is not used as a primary treatment for PMR.

nbme_correct_explanation: Fibrocystic changes of the breast occur most commonly in premenopausal women. Patients may present with various sites of breast pain and lumps, which may be bilateral. The condition is characterized by the presence of cysts, stromal fibrosis, and apocrine metaplasia on histology, and is believed to occur in response to hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle. Reexamination after menses (eg, day 9 of the next menstrual cycle) may be helpful for diagnosis because the size of fibrocystic changes should subside after menses, distinguishing it from other causes. On examination, the cysts may appear blue. Fibrocystic change is a benign disease and does not generally convey an increased risk for cancer except for certain subtypes; however, it can result in recurrent mastalgia. If there is associated discomfort, aspiration can be performed, which may relieve symptoms. Cyst aspiration can yield fluid that is clear, milky, yellow, green, or brown, which are all benign. Supportive care is also appropriate, using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and a well-fitting bra.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Measurement of serum prolactin concentration (Choice B) is useful in the evaluation of galactorrhea and menstrual cycle irregularities (eg, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea) because of its inhibition of gonadotropin-releasing hormone. Galactorrhea refers to milky discharge from one or both nipples, which this patient is not experiencing.
Mammography (Choice C) is most used as a screening modality to detect early stages of breast cancer, although it may also be used to aid in the diagnosis of a palpable breast mass. However, ultrasonography is more commonly used to aid in diagnosis for patients under age 35 years, as their breast tissue is often too dense to be adequately evaluated with mammography.
Ultrasonography of the breasts (Choice D) is frequently used in the evaluation of breast lesions for patients under age 35 years. It can determine the need for fine-needle aspiration (eg, breast cyst) or further imaging. This patient has no palpable breast lump, which would make ultrasonography ineffective in evaluating her symptoms. If performed, it would likely show multiple small cystic lesions.
MRI of the breasts (Choice E) may be used for the evaluation of a breast lump in patients under age 35 years, but it is more commonly reserved for evaluation of patients with breast implants or those with a high risk for developing breast cancer (eg, BRCA mutation carriers). This patient may require additional imaging in the future, but she should first have a repeat examination on day 9 of her next menstrual cycle.
